name: 3-amino-5-methylthio-1h-pyrazole-4-carbonitrile
Reason: The compound 3-amino-5-methylthio-1h-pyrazole-4-carbonitrile has multiple functional groups that influence its melting point. The basic pyrazole ring system typically has a melting point (though this can vary widely depending on substitution). Amino groups (-NH2) can increase the melting point due to the ability to form intermolecular hydrogen bonds, which can be estimated as a +50 units increase. The nitrile group (C#N) has a strong dipole and may engage in dipole-dipole interactions that would increase the melting point; this may add approximately +20 units. The methylthio group (-SCH3) adds both bulk and the ability for van der Waals interactions, which might increase the melting point further by about +30 units.
Prediction: Base pyrazole melting point +50 (amino) +20 (nitrile) +30 (methylthio) = Base pyrazole melting point +100. If we estimate the base pyrazole melting point around 50 units based on typical heteroaromatics, the predicted melting point would be 150 units, which is very close to the actual value of 149.0
